result.rationale: This species is listed as Endangered, in view of area of occupancy (AOO) of 68 km<sup>2</sup>, with all observed individuals in three threat-based locations and a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat related to conversion of forests to agriculture and pollution.
result.geographicrange: This species occurs in the foothills of the western Venezuelan Andes, in the rivers Yaracuy, Aroa, Urama, Capa, Guarataro, Crucito and Carabobo, that drain towards the Caribbean Sea.
result.population: There are no data available to estimate the population size.
result.habitat: This species has been collected from mountain to coastal streams and rivers with riparian forest, with bottoms of cobble and boulders, associated with the fastest flowing waters of riffles (Ceas and Page 1996).
result.threats: Around 40% of its distribution has been converted to agricultural use for cattle ranch farms (Oliveira et al. 2010), all of which is causing habitat loss for this species. The main threats take place in Yaracuy River, which has been polluted with waste waters from urban, industrial and agricultural areas. Additionally, some of the tributaries have been blocked by the construction of dams, and the deforestation of riparian forests is widespread (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011).
result.conservationmeasures: Around 30% of the distribution is within the national parks of Yurubi and Cueva de la Quebrada del Toro. However, most of it occurs in highly degraded areas. This species would benefit from habitat restoration and better information on distribution, abundance and population trends.
result.usetrade: It is unknown if this species is traded in the ornamental fish market.
